newsitem.title: FRANCE: Dassault sees 96 profit in line with H1.
newsitem.headline: Dassault sees 96 profit in line with H1.

text.p: French aircraft maker Dassault Aviation expects its pretax pre-exceptional profit for full-year 1996 to be in line with the trend seen in the first half, finance director Charles Edelstenne said on Friday.
Pretax pre-exceptional profit for 1996 "will confirm" the first-half trend, he told journalists.
The pre-exceptional result will exclude the capital gain made from the flotation of a stake in Dassault Systemes in the first half, he said.
Dassault Aviation made a first-half pretax profit of 1.26 billion francs including the exceptional gain from Dassault Systemes, compared to a year ago profit of 277 million.
Dassault Aviation made a net attributable profit for the full-year 1995 of 401 million francs, up from 328 million in 1994.

New orders this year would be lower than 1995 and would be inferior to 1996 turnover for the first time in a number of years as the government had not ordered any Rafale jets this year, Edelstenne said.
The French government has delayed 1996 orders for the Rafale combat jet and pushed back the production programme, he said.
But the government has budgeted four billion francs for the Rafale programme for 1997, and Dassault hoped there would be orders in that year, he said.
Dassault Aviation posted 1995 pretax pre-exceptional profit of 475 million francs versus 397 million in 1994.
